subject: resource/Benjamin_Tupper
object: Benjamin Tupper (March 11, 1738 – June 16, 1792) was a soldier in the French and Indian War, and an officer of the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War, achieving the rank of brevet brigadier general. Subsequently, he served as a Massachusetts legislator, and he assisted Gen. William Shepard in stopping Shays' Rebellion. Benjamin Tupper was a co-founder of the Ohio Company of Associates, and was a pioneer to the Ohio Country, involved in establishing Marietta, Ohio as the first permanent settlement in the Northwest Territory.
human_readable: Benjamin Tupper was a soldier, officer, legislator, and pioneer who achieved the rank of brevet brigadier general and played key roles in the French and Indian War, American Revolutionary War, Shays' Rebellion, and the establishment of Marietta, Ohio.
